data.title: Barbara Matias Haynes on LinkedIn: Years ago when I was in brand marketing I had a manager who openly spoke…
data.meta_description: Years ago when I was in brand marketing I had a manager who openly spoke negatively about others in my peer group, which I knew meant that he did the same to…
data.text:
LinkedIn and 3rd parties use essential and non-essential cookies to provide, secure, analyze and improve our Services, and to show you relevant ads (including professional and job ads) on and off LinkedIn. Learn more in our Cookie Policy.

Select Accept to consent or Reject to decline non-essential cookies for this use. You can update your choices at any time in your settings.

Years ago when I was in brand marketing I had a manager who openly spoke negatively about others in my peer group, which I knew meant that he did the same to me when I was not in the room. This not so subtle tactic is just a small sign of how easy it is to perpetuate a dehumanized view of your staff as "resources" framed in a setting of delivering results at any cost. I love how Susan David highlights that these organizations "fail to recognize that employee wellbeing is integral to overall organizational success." To keep organizations healthy, thriving and creative, skills such as emotional regulation, authenticity and compassion are ones that should be utilized regularly; without them, we are impeding the overall success of the organization. What I have learned over my years in coaching is that the power of helping my staff, students or clients to be aware of and strengthen these "human skills" has led to positive impacts in their relationships at work and in life. Leaders, let's keep encouraging this skill and modeling the same.
